Name: Cinnamon
Notes: Forked from GNOME 3 with the intent to create a traditional desktop with modern technologies.

Name: Enlightenment (E)
Notes: Complete environment including centralized configuration of most settings.

Name: Equinox Desktop Environment (EDE)
Notes: Seldom used environment, has seen little activity in recent years.

Name: Étoilé
Notes: Has seen little activity for several years, the last journal entry having been in 2014.

Name: GNOME
Notes: GNOME is one of the most popular environments and is very configurable. Major design changes with the 3.0 release sparked the creation of Cinnamon (a fork of GNOME 3), Unity (an alternative GNOME 3 shell replacing GNOME Shell) and MATE (a fork of GNOME 2).

Name: KDE Plasma 5 (KDE5, KDE Plasma Workspaces, formerly K Desktop Environment or simply KDE)
Notes: KDE has a strong and enthusiastic following, despite a reputation for being resource-intensive. The project is largely community-centric, and encompass many other applications and frameworks, many built specifically for KDE.

Name: LXDE (Lightweight X11 Desktop Environment)
Notes: LXDE, with its low resource footprint, is a favorite among developers of lighter-weight Linux distributions (Lubuntu, Lite, LXLE, PepperMint, Sparky, etc.).

Name: LXQt
Notes: merged from LXDE-Qt experiment and Razor-qt

Name: MATE
Notes: Revival and continuation of GNOME 2 environment after the release of GNOME 3. In recent releases, it has been ported to GTK+ 3, demonstrating the progress of the project.

Name: Trinity Desktop Environment (TDE)
Notes: forked from KDE 3.x Intentionally with a Win-XP look.

Name: Unity
Notes: Developed by Canonical for Ubuntu as an alternative graphical shell to GNOME 3's "GNOME Shell". Designed with "convergence" in mind, it was discontinued by Canonical in early 2017, but its development was continued by the community.

Name: Xfce
Notes: XFCE is often used in lightweight distributions targeting lower-end hardware.
